why: Provides types and functions for interacting with the SPL Token program, including Mint, TokenAccount, and CPI helpers
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't use SPL Token types or functions - compilation error

what: Instruction to create a new token mint
why: A token mint is the source of truth for a token type. It defines the token's properties (decimals, supply, etc.)
whatBreaksIfRemoved: No way to create tokens - core functionality missing

what: Instruction to mint new tokens into a token account
why: Minting creates new tokens and adds them to the total supply. Only the mint authority can mint
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't create new tokens - supply is fixed at zero

what: CPI call to the SPL Token program's mint_to instruction
why: This is a Cross-Program Invocation - our program calls into the SPL Token program to perform the minting
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Tokens aren't actually minted - just a log message

what: Creates a CPI context with the required accounts
why: CPI contexts specify which accounts the called program needs and their roles (mint, to, authority)
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't pass accounts to SPL Token program - CPI fails

what: Instruction to transfer tokens between token accounts
why: Demonstrates how to move tokens from one account to another, which is fundamental to token operations
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't move tokens - they're locked in accounts

what: CPI call to the SPL Token program's transfer instruction
why: Transfers tokens by calling into the SPL Token program, which handles all the account updates
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Tokens don't actually move - transfer fails

what: Account struct for creating a token mint
why: Defines all accounts needed to create a mint, with Anchor constraints that handle initialization
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't create mints - missing account structure

what: Init constraint for the mint account
why: Tells Anchor to initialize the mint account if it doesn't exist
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Mint account isn't created - initialization fails

why: Decimals define the smallest unit of the token. 9 is standard (like SOL). 1 token = 1,000,000,000 base units
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Mint has wrong decimals - token amounts are incorrect

why: The mint authority is the only account that can mint new tokens. This is critical for supply control
whatBreaksIfRemoved: No mint authority set - can't mint tokens

why: Defines accounts needed: the mint, destination token account, and mint authority
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't specify accounts for minting - CPI fails

why: Defines source, destination, and authority accounts needed for a token transfer
whatBreaksIfRemoved: Can't specify accounts for transfer - CPI fails
